tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: In you, Yahweh, I take refuge
tn.text: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "I go to you, Yahweh, for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "do not let others humiliate me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: be my rock of refuge, a stronghold to save me
tn.text: The phrase "be my rock of refuge" is a request for protection. The second phrase emphasizes the first phrase. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Yahweh is spoke of as if he were a huge rock that would protect the writer from attack. AT: "like a huge rock on which I can be safe" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh is spoken of as if he were a strong fortress in which the writer would be protected from his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh is spoke of as if he were a huge rock that would protect the writer from attack. AT: "like a huge rock on which I can be safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh is spoken of as if he were a strong fortress in which the writer would be protected from his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
In this phrase "name" represents Yahweh. AT: "so that your name may be honored" or "so that I may worship you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The words "lead" and "guide" mean basically the same thing and strengthen the request that Yahweh lead him. AT: "lead me where you want me to go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Pluck me out of the net that they have hidden for me
tn.text: The writer is spoken of as if he were a bird caught in a hidden net, and waiting for Yahweh to free him from the trap. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Yahweh is spoken of as if he is a place where the writer can hide from people who are attacking him. AT: "you always protect me" or "you give me constant protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

God is spirit, but he is here spoken of as if he has hands. Here "your hands" refers to Yahweh's care. AT: "Into your care" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "my spirit" refers to the writer. AT: "I place myself" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"you are a God I can trust"

tn.ref: I hate those who serve worthless idols
tn.text: "Idols are worthless. I hate those who serve them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])

tn.ref: you saw my affliction ... you knew the distress of my soul
tn.text: Both of these phrases express the idea that God knows about the writer's troubles. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "my soul" refers to the writer. AT: "my distress"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "my feet" refers to the writer. AT: "You have set me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The Hebrews thought of wide open spaces as a metaphor for safety and freedom. AT: "a place where I am free" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"I am suffering greatly"
The terms "soul" and "body" are used to describe the complete person.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "my life" refers to the writer. AT: "I have become very weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"because of my sorrow ... because of my groaning"
The phrase "is weary" is missing, but is implied. AT: "my years are weary with groaning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Here "My strength" refers to the writer. AT: "I have become weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "my bones" refers to the physical health of the writer. AT: "my health is failing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"people insult me"
"are shocked at my condition"

tn.ref: as a dead man whom no one thinks about
tn.text: The writer says people have so forgotten him the it is as if he were already dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
The writer speaks of himself as if he was completely useless. "as useless as a broken pot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
It is implied that "many" refers to people. AT: "many people talking about me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"scary reports from many sources"
This idiom means to kill someone. AT: "kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: My destiny is in your hand
tn.text: Here "your hand" refers to Yahweh's power. AT: "You have the power to decide my future" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"from people who try to capture me"

tn.ref: Make your face shine on your servant
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards him as if Yahweh's face shone a light on him. AT: "Act favorably towards your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not let me be humiliated
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Do not let others make me feel ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"I wish that God would disgrace wicked people!"
This refers to "wicked people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: May they be silent in Sheol. May lying lips be silenced
tn.text: This idea is repeated to emphasize the writer's desire that the voices of the wicked are not heard. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: May they be silent in Sheol
tn.text: Here "in Sheol" represents death. AT: "Let them die so they cannot speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These represent lying people. AT: "people who lie" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: that speak against the righteous defiantly
tn.text: Here "the righteous" refers to people who are righteous. AT: "that say terrible things about righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
These terms have similar meanings. AT: "with a complete lack of respect"
This can be expressed with a verb. AT: "are the good things you do"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Yahweh's goodness is spoken of as if it was something that could be stored up like a harvest. AT: "that you are keeping ready to use" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"those who respect you greatly"

Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:031:001|31:1]]. AT: "those who go to you for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: In the shelter of your presence, you hide them ... You hide them in a shelter
tn.text: These phrases both mean that God protects them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Yahweh's presence is spoken of as if it is a strong building where the writer would be safe. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You hide them in a shelter
tn.text: Here a "shelter" represents a safe place. AT: "You provide a safe place for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "tongues" refer to the people who are speaking violent things against the writer. AT: "where their enemies cannot speak evil at them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I am cut off from your eyes
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "You have removed me from your presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "eyes" refers to Yahweh's presence. AT: "your presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you heard my plea for help
tn.text: Here "plea" can be expressed with a verb. AT: "you heard me plead for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This refers to the faithful people. AT: "the people  who are faithful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: he pays back the arrogant in full
tn.text: Here "pay back" is an idiom that refers to punishment. AT: "he gives the proud people all of the punishment that they deserve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
